thoughts.a: Input and output grids are very different sizes. input grid is large and the output grid is much smaller than the input grid. We notice immediately that the input grid looks like a uniform patter with the exception of a red square bounding box. Input grid looks like a bunch of different colors and patterns, specifically many horizontal and vertical aqua lines that seem to split up the input grid into various subsections. These subsections have black, green, and blue tiles in them. The main outlier in the input grid is that red bounding box. The output grid is an exact copy of the red bounding box and its contents. Thus, the hypothesis is the following. Input the gradient will be a large amount of tiles that has Some design or pattern in it composed of potentially many colors. one section of the input grid will be highlighted or selected with a red bounding box. In order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the exact tiles that make up this red bounding box and the interior of it. It seems like nothing else matters in the input grid.
thoughts.b: Input and output grids again have very different sizes. Input grid is again composed of a variety of different overlapping patterns, primarily made up with gray, yellow, red, and aqua lines that span the input grid on a black color background. Immediately what stands out is the green bounding box. According to the hypothesis, this should have been a red bounding box, So our hypothesis was actually too specific and we need to generalize it. The output grid indeed has the contents of the green bounding box and the green layer itself, so we still need to copy over the identified different section. Thus the amended hypothesis is the following. Input grid will have a large amount of tiles in it. It will be composed of a variety of colored lines, stacked on top of each other, on a black color background. These lines generally span the entirety of the input grid from edge to edge. Also in the input grid there will be a bounding box of a unique color, not one used in any of the lines. In this case it was green. In order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the bounding box and the interior tiles, exactly as is, to the output grid. The output grid's size is determined by the size of this bounding box.
thoughts.c: Input grid is a variety of overlapping horizontal and vertical lines. In this case, the colors of those lines are gray, aqua, green, and blue on a black colored background. According to the hypothesis, there should be a bounding box that exists in a color that is not any of those colored lines. We see in the input grid that there is a pink bounding box. In order to construct the output grid, we have to copy the contents of this pink bounding box, including the pink tile layer on the outside to the output grid. This is the entirety of the output grid, and the size of the output grid is set by the size of this identified bounding box. Because this is what we see in the output grid here, the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.d: We apply the hypothesis here. Input grid is composed of a variety of overlapping horizontal and vertical colored lines. In this case, we have yellow, green, red, and blue lines that generally go from edge to edge on a black color background. According to the hypothesis, there should be a bounding box of a unique color that is not one of those colors. We see here in the input grid, there is an aqua bounding box. In order to construct the output grid, we need to copy over the interior tiles of this aqua bounding box exactly as is in the input grid, including the aqua tiles that make up the bounding box itself. The output grid should be the same size as this aqua bounding box.
